questions.text: Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? Glutaraldehyde Ethylene oxide Pasteurization Orthophthalaldehyde
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 1,2 and 4

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. AIRE

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with organophosphate poisoning. The treatment team considers various options to counteract the overwhelming parasympathetic activity while taking into account the efficacy of the chosen drug in reversing actions of endogenous and exogenous acetylcholine. Drug X is effective in reversing the actions induced by the parasympathetic nervous system in vivo but fails to counteract the actions of exogenously administered acetylcholine in in-vitro experiments. Which of the following is most likely to be Drug X?
Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. 1

questions.text: Identify the true statements: TxA2 has platelet aggregating and vasoconstricting effect Lipoxin B4 inhibits inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium. Il-1, Il-18, TNF are pyrogenic cytokines C3 can be activated is both common as well as alternative pathways T cells with a TCR composed of a γ and δ subunit are found associated with GI mucosa
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 1,2,4,5

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?

options.label: A
options.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli

options.label: B
options.text: Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

options.label: C
options.text: Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis

options.label: D
options.text: Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.correct_answer: B. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is admitted to the hospital for elective knee surgery. She has previously been managed with unfractionated heparin. Her physician is contemplating the potential benefits and drawbacks of switching her to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for perioperative thromboprophylaxis. As compared to unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparins:

options.label: A
options.text: Are absorbed more uniformly when given subcutaneously

options.label: C
options.text: Can be given to patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia

options.label: D
options.text: Predispose to a higher risk of osteopenia

questions.correct_answer: A. Are absorbed more uniformly when given subcutaneously
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Are absorbed more uniformly when given subcutaneously

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • B) Require more frequent laboratory monitoring: LMWHs actually require less frequent laboratory monitoring than unfractionated heparin, owing to their more predictable pharmacokinetics.
  • • C) Can be given to patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia: Patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia should avoid all forms of heparin, including LMWHs.
  • • D) Predispose to a higher risk of osteopenia: Both unfractionated heparin and LMWHs have been associated with a risk of osteopenia with long-term use, but LMWHs are not generally considered to present a higher risk than unfractionated heparin.
  • • Thus, among the given options, "Are absorbed more uniformly when given subcutaneously" is the correct answer.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? Candidiasis Aspergillosis Pneumocystis pneumonia Mucormycosis Cryptococcus Blastomyces
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 4,5,6

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus is consulting with his healthcare provider about treatment options to manage his elevated blood sugar levels. His provider considers prescribing sitagliptin as part of his treatment plan. Sitagliptin is least likely to reduce blood sugar in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Non-diabetics

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • B) Obese diabetics: Sitagliptin can be effective in obese patients with diabetes as it works by increasing insulin secretion and reducing glucagon levels, which are mechanisms not directly affected by obesity.
  • • C) Type 2 diabetics: Sitagliptin is specifically indicated for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, so it would be expected to reduce blood sugar in these patients.
  • • D) Diabetics not responding to sulfonylureas: Sitagliptin has a different mechanism of action than sulfonylureas. Patients who do not respond to sulfonylureas might still respond to sitagliptin.
  • • Therefore, sitagliptin is least likely to reduce blood sugar in non-diabetics, making A the correct answer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with advanced non-small cell lung cancer has been started on pembrolizumab as part of her treatment plan. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets PD-1, effectively boosting the immune response against cancer cells. Three weeks into her treatment, she starts to experience symptoms including fatigue, muscle weakness, and some joint pain, raising concerns about potential adverse effects of the drug. Which of the following adverse effects is NOT commonly associated with immune checkpoint inhibitors like pembrolizumab?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • A) Autoimmune colitis: This is a known complication of immune checkpoint inhibitors. Patients may present with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and even bloody stools. This is due to the immune system attacking the lining of the intestine.
  • • C) Thyroid dysfunction: Checkpoint inhibitors can cause both hypo- and hyperthyroidism by triggering autoimmunity against the thyroid gland. Patients may present with symptoms such as fatigue, weight changes, and palpitations.
  • • D) Pneumonitis: This is inflammation of the lung tissue, another potential adverse effect of checkpoint inhibitors. It can present with symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and even acute respiratory distress if severe.
  • • The development of these side effects often requires close monitoring, and sometimes cessation of the drug and initiation of corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: 38-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated for new-onset confusion. The patient has a prolonged history of Crohn disease and was admitted 2 days ago due to worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and watery diarrhea. She tested positive for Clostridium difficile infection and is receiving oral vancomycin and intravenous fluids. Her gastrointestinal symptoms have been improving, but since yesterday the patient has been incoherent, disoriented, and unsteady. She has no other medical conditions but has had small bowel resections due to stricture and fistula in the past and has lost 10 kg (22 lbs) over the past 6 months. On examination, she is not oriented to time or place. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Abduction of the right eye is limited and elicits bilateral horizontal nystagmus. Motor strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal throughout. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal, but the gait is wide based. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Nutritional vitamin deficiency

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:
questions.explanation: Ans. C.

questions.text: 6-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery. He was born at 39 weeks’ gestation via spontaneous vagina delivery to a 33-year-old primigravida. The pregnancy was complicated by intravenous drug use. First trimester serologies, including RPR, HIV antibodies, and hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), were negative. Due to the mother's risk profile, follow-up testing was obtained during the third trimester and revealed the following lab values: HBSAg-Positive Anti-HBsAg Negative IgM Anti-HBcAg Negative Anti-HBcAg Positive Anti HCV negative Liver function testing was normal. The remainder of the pregnancy was uncomplicated. The infant weighs 3.7 kg (8 lb 3 oz). Physical examination of the infant is normal. There is no jaundice or hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management this infant?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.text: 4-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns of appearing pale. Over the past few days, he has been sleeping more than usual and is less interactive. He continues to have good urine output. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation and had a normal nursery course. However, the patient's newborn screen revealed an extra band representing beta tetramers on hemoglobin electrophoresis. The patient takes a vitamin D supplement daily. Vital signs are normal. He appears tired and has mild scleral icterus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. HbH disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old epileptic female was stabilized on phenytoin therapy since 2 years. Recently she presented with weakness and fatigue. She appears pale and pulse was rapid. Her hemogram reveals: Hb = 4.6 g% TLC = 7000/mm 3 Platelet count = 180000/mm 3 MCV = 76 fl MCH = 24 pg/dl How will you proceed for the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start folic acid as it is likely to be phenytoin induced megaloblastic anemia.

options.label: B
options.text: Investigate on the line of iron deficiency anemia

options.label: C
options.text: Stop phenytoin and start some other antiepileptic drug as it is phenytoin induced agranulocytosis

options.label: D
options.text: Give vitamin B 12 injections as it is likely to be phenytoin induced megaloblastic anemia

questions.correct_answer: B. Investigate on the line of iron deficiency anemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Investigate on the line of iron deficiency anemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • A) Start folic acid as it is likely to be phenytoin induced megaloblastic anemia: This would not be appropriate because the MCV and MCH values suggest a microcytic, hypochromic anemia rather than a megaloblastic one.
  • • C) Stop phenytoin and start some other antiepileptic drug as it is phenytoin induced agranulocytosis: This option is not suitable because the total leukocyte count is within the normal range, making agranulocytosis unlikely.
  • • D) Give vitamin B12 injections as it is likely to be phenytoin induced megaloblastic anemia: Similar to option A, the lab values do not support a diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia.
  • • In this case, the patient's symptoms and lab findings are most consistent with iron deficiency anemia, making option B the best course of action for further management.

questions.text: A man has an aneurysm in the aortic root, a consequence of Marfan’s syndrome. He experiences a hypertensive crisis that requires prompt blood pressure control. Nitroprusside will be infused for its immediate antihypertensive effects. Which of the following drugs must be administered along with the nitroprusside to minimize the risk of aneurysm rupture as blood pressure falls?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Propranolol.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • A) Atropine: This drug is an anticholinergic that increases heart rate and would likely increase shear stress on the aortic wall, which is undesirable in this situation.
  • • C) Furosemide: This diuretic could help lower blood pressure but would not directly address the force of cardiac contractions or shear stress on the aneurysm wall.
  • • D) Phentolamine: This is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that would primarily affect vascular tone and reduce blood pressure but would not reduce the force of cardiac contractions.
  • • Given the specific need to reduce the shear stress on an aneurysm in a hypertensive crisis, Propranolol is the most appropriate drug to administer alongside nitroprusside.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with advanced breast cancer is being treated with chemotherapy. Despite an initial response, the tumor eventually becomes resistant to treatment and starts growing rapidly. Further investigation reveals dysregulation of glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) and increased lipid peroxidation in tumor cells. Which of the following forms of regulated cell death is likely contributing to the resistance to chemotherapy in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Ferroptosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of chronic insomnia is prescribed a medication as part of her treatment plan. The medical team is evaluating the pharmacokinetic properties of the drug, specifically focusing on how the drug's ionization affects its absorption and distribution within the body. Which of the following statements regarding drug ionization is LEAST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The pKa of a drug corresponds to the pH at which half of the drug molecules are ionized.

options.label: B
options.text: Minor shifts in pH near the pKa of a weak acidic drug have a minimal impact on its degree of ionization.

options.label: C
options.text: The pKa value of a drug can be useful for predicting its pharmacological behavior in different bodily fluids.

options.label: D
options.text: Phenobarbital, with a pKa value of 7.2, remains mostly unionized in acidic conditions and is around 40% non-ionized in plasma.

questions.correct_answer: B. Minor shifts in pH near the pKa of a weak acidic drug have a minimal impact on its degree of ionization.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Minor shifts in pH near the pKa of a weak acidic drug have a minimal impact on its degree of ionization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who underwent a heart transplant one year ago visits her cardiologist for a routine check-up. The physician is considering various pharmacological agents that might affect her heart rate differently compared to individuals with native hearts. Which of the following drugs will decrease heart rate in a patient with a normal heart but will have no effect on heart rate in a cardiac transplant recipient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Phenylephrine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • Adrenaline (Option A) is a potent agonist at both alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors. It usually increases heart rate in both a normal heart as well as transplanted heart.
  • • Noradrenaline (Option B) acts primarily as an alpha-agonist but also has some beta-agonist activity. Due to its strong vasoconstrictor activity, it leads to reflex bradycardia in a normal person. However, this reflex arc is disrupted in cardiac transplant patients and thus the direct beta1 activity result in tachycardia.
  • • Isoproterenol (Option C) is a non-selective beta-adrenergic agonist. It stimulates beta-1 receptors on the heart and increases heart rate in both normal as well as transplanted heart.

questions.text: 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He underwent a splenectomy a year ago for persistent anemia and jaundice. He has received the pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations and takes penicillin prophylaxis. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing child . The sclerae are anicteric. The abdomen is soft and nontender; no masses are palpable. Several well-healed laparoscopy scars are noted. Complete blood count is as follows: Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL Reticulocytes : 3% Platelets : 160,000/mm³ Leukocytes: 8,200/mm³ Peripheral blood smear with Wright stain is shown. This patient's findings are most likely related to which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Inability to produce beta globin chains

options.label: D
options.text: Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.correct_answer: D. Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension is being considered for a new antihypertensive medication. His physician is weighing various options, taking into consideration their potential impact on plasma renin activity, which could have downstream effects on blood pressure control. All of the following drugs increase plasma renin activity except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Methyl dopa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • A) Amlodipine: This calcium channel blocker reduces arterial pressure and typically triggers a compensatory increase in renin release to restore blood pressure, thereby increasing plasma renin activity.
  • • C) Enalapril: This angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor reduces levels of angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor that also inhibits renin release. Lower angiotensin II levels result in increased renin activity.
  • • D) Prazosin: This alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist reduces vascular tone, leading to a compensatory increase in renin release to restore blood pressure, thereby increasing plasma renin activity.
  • • Therefore, among the options given, Methyl dopa is the drug that does not typically increase plasma renin activity.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office due to a week of low-grade fever, dry cough, and right-sided chest pain. The pain is intermittent, sharp, and worse with deep inhalation or cough. The patient also notes mild "achiness" in his knees and ankles that started around the same time. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient is an Army officer, and he returned after completing desert training exercises in Rajasthan. He does not know if other participants developed similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F). blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 16/min. Lung auscultation shows right-sided crackles. No joint swelling or tenderness is present, but there are erythematous, tender nodules on the bilateral shins. Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate with a prominent right hilum. Which of the following is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Coccidioides immitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a two-week history of fatigue, lower extremity edema, and frothy urine. He has no history of serious illnesses. Physical examination shows symmetric pitting edema of lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria. Electron microscopy of the specimen obtained from kidney biopsy shows dense deposits within glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence microscopy is positive for C3, not immunoglobulins. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism that explains this patient's condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

questions.correct_answer: C. Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

questions.text: Match the following images associated with GI polyps with the likely diagnosis: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome Gardner syndrome Turcot syndrome Cowden syndrome Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome Peutz-Jegher syndrome syndrome
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 1-D, 2-F, 3-C, 4-B

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of recurrent cellulitis is seen by his primary care physician. He has previously been managed with various antibiotics including penicillins and cephalosporins. The physician is considering which antibiotic to prescribe and is mindful of their pharmacokinetics and bioavailability. Which of the following statements about the biodisposition of penicillins and cephalosporins is NOT accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Glomerular filtration of beta-lactams is inhibited by probenecid

options.label: B
options.text: Oral bioavailability is affected by lability to gastric acid

options.label: C
options.text: Procaine penicillin G is used via intramuscular injection

options.label: D
options.text: Ceftriaxone and cefoperazone are eliminated mainly via biliary secretion

questions.correct_answer: A. Glomerular filtration of beta-lactams is inhibited by probenecid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Glomerular filtration of beta-lactams is inhibited by probenecid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation for Other Options:
  • • B) Oral bioavailability is affected by lability to gastric acid: This is true. The oral bioavailability of some penicillins can be significantly reduced by gastric acid.
  • • C) Procaine penicillin G is used via intramuscular injection: This is also true. Procaine penicillin G is designed to be administered via intramuscular injection to provide a prolonged release of the drug.
  • • D) Ceftriaxone and cefoperazone are eliminated mainly via biliary secretion: This statement is accurate. Ceftriaxone is primarily eliminated through the biliary system, and cefoperazone is eliminated both via the biliary system and the urinary system.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and altered mental status. She was in her usual state of health until 5 days ago, when she developed a low-grade fever, malaise, headache, cough coryza, and a sore throat. The fever resolved with over-the-counter aspirin. The patient developed nausea, vomiting, and lethargy this morning. Examination shows a febrile, sleepy girl with hepatomegaly. There is no jaundice or splenomegaly. The patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. Laboratory results are as follows Hemoglobin-14.2 g/L Platelets-180,000/mm³ Leukocytes-8,300/ mm³ Blood urea nitrogen-16 mg/dL Creatinine-0.6 mg/dL Glucose-72 mg/dL Total bilirubin-0.9 mg/dL Ammonia-94 mcg/dL (normal: <45 mcg/dL) Percutaneous liver biopsy would most likely reveal which of the following in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies

questions.explanation: Ans. C. Microvesicular fatty infiltration

questions.text: 22-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks gestation comes to the office for her initial prenatal visit. She has no symptoms except mild nausea. She smoked a pack of cigarettes a day and drank 7-8 beers each week but quit after learning she was pregnant. The patient has a history of an allergic reaction to penicillin; she developed a generalized rash with intense itching that responded to antihistamines and corticosteroid cream. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The screening VDRL test is positive, fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is positive. Her HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Skin testing and penicillin desensitization
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Skin testing and penicillin desensitization

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match with respect to the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drugs?

options.label: A
options.text: Zavegepant - CGRP receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks

options.label: B
options.text: Pembrolizumab - Immune check point inhibitor used for endometrial carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Ertugliflozin - SGLT2 inhibitor for treatment of diabetes mellitus

options.label: D
options.text: Ivabradine - Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity

questions.correct_answer: D. Ivabradine - Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ivabradine - Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Zavegepant - CGRP receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks: This is a correct match. Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist. It is used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. CGRP is a neuropeptide that plays a role in the pathophysiology of migraines, and antagonists like Zavegepant block its activity, thereby alleviating symptoms.
  • • B) Pembrolizumab – Immune check point inhibitor used for endometrial carcinoma: This is also a correct match. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets the PD-1 receptor. It is used for a variety of cancers, including endometrial carcinoma, especially in cases that are MSI-H or dMMR (microsatellite instability-high or mismatch repair deficient).
  • • C) Ertugliflozin – SGLT2 inhibitor for treatment of diabetes mellitus: This is another correct match. Ertugliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, which is used to manage blood sugar levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, thereby leading to the excretion of glucose in the urine.
  • • D) Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity: This is the incorrect match. Ivabradine is indeed a "funny" current (If) blocker, but it is used for the treatment of certain types of chronic heart failure and angina pectoris (chest pain), not for treating decreased visual acuity.
  • • Therefore, option D is not a correct match concerning the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drug.

questions.text: Match the following case scenarios with the likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation: Ans. D. 1-C, 2-E, 3-G, 4-D

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is taken to a neurologist by her family members. After thorough evaluation, the neurologist suggests the possibility of starting Aducanumab therapy, and the patient's family starts researching the medication. Which of the following statements about Aducanumab is FALSE?

options.label: B
options.text: Aducanumab works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase to increase cholinergic transmission.

options.label: C
options.text: Aducanumab has received FDA approval for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Aducanumab targets amyloid-beta plaques in the brain.

questions.correct_answer: B. Aducanumab works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase to increase cholinergic transmission.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Aducanumab works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase to increase cholinergic transmission.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Aducanumab is a monoclonal antibody: This statement is TRUE. Aducanumab is a monoclonal antibody designed to treat Alzheimer's disease by targeting amyloid-beta plaques in the brain.
  • • B) Aducanumab works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase to increase cholinergic transmission: This statement is FALSE. Aducanumab does not work by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase. Its primary mechanism is to target and remove amyloid-beta plaques.
  • • C) Aducanumab has received FDA approval for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease: This statement is TRUE. Although its approval has been met with some controversy and debate, Aducanumab has been conditionally approved by the FDA for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
  • • D) Aducanumab targets amyloid-beta plaques in the brain: This statement is TRUE. The drug is designed to bind to amyloid-beta plaques, thereby aiding in their removal and potentially slowing the progression of Alzheimer's disease, although definitive evidence for clinical benefit is still being evaluated.
  • • Thus, the statement that is FALSE about Aducanumab is that it works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase to increase cholinergic transmission.
